ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: I spent about 6 hours when assignments were due, and about 1-2 hours to do some readings. It never felt overwhelming.
About 2 hours per week on average
7-8 hours/week during homework assignment weeks
2h
On weeks with homework, 6 hours. On weeks without homework, I spent an hour previewing the chapter. On the week with the final, I spent 15 hours.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I loved this class. It looked at topics that were first presented in BIS 540 in more depth. Its strengths are in its instructor and the excellent textbook. I can think of no real weaknesses, except that the final was worth 60% and we did not really know what to expect (no practice tests, etc.). However, it turned out to be very fair and similar to homework. Also, I do not think inviting the lecturer from Takeda was necessary. At the end of the day, I did not feel it was a good use of our time and I would have much rather had Dr. Peduzzi do another lecture. My suggestion is to make the Takeda talk optional, after gauging student interest. I feel like I learned a lot in the course.
I really liked this course. I especially appreciated how professor Peduzzi integrated theory with real world applications.
I learned a lot in this course and enjoyed the professor. The material was more clearly presented than in other "biostats for clinical trials" courses I've taken.
Outstanding course and I would not recommend any changes.

Really well-paced, interesting course that sought for depth in understanding, rather than rushing through the material. I actually feel like I learned the material we went over, unlike my other BIS courses. Perhaps would be better as a year-long course (i.e. offer part I and part II). Given the fact that "case studies" is in the title, I was hoping for more options for discussion/small group work, but there were almost too many students for this to really have functioned well (and I don't think the classroom was set up for this).

Course material is fantastic for anyone interested in the design, analysis, and conduct of clinical trials. It's actually very similar to the course offered in the fall, fundamentals of clinical trials, but much more structured... Could consider combining the courses...

I felt this course really highlighted and expanded on the important aspects of clinical trials that were briefly introduced by Epi II. The amount of work in relation to how much information I feel like I've gained was very reasonable.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  Dr. Peduzzi was a very likeable and interesting lecturer who focused more on student understanding than on "getting through" material.The slides provided were excellent, as was the textbook. In addition, I appreciated that Dr. Peduzzi went over the homework with us to make sure we understood material. He made it a point to learn everyone's name, and was one of the best professors I have had. I would only suggest one improvement-- make use of the classesv2 system to upload grades and announcements about due dates, date of the exam, etc., especially since we changed the schedule so much.

Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  Professor Peduzzi was great. I really appreciated how he didn't rush through the material but took his time and made sure we absorbed it. It helped me to get a lot more out of the class.
Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  I thought the instructor was well prepared and understanding.

Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  Dr. Peduzzi is an outstanding teacher. He has a wealth of knowledge and experience of working with clinical trials, which he graciously shares with future generations of students.
Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  Absolutely fabulous. Really knowledgeable and approachable; teaching style/pedagogy is a good fit for the course and for graduate level.
Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  Wonderful instructor. Loves interacting with students. Smart, funny

Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  He's a brilliant professor. Wrote an amazing book. Course is somewhat dry because it follows said book pretty closely. But the book is great, so I guess can't really complain.

Instructor: Peter Natale Peduzzi  I really liked Peter's teaching style. He spent a lot of time making sure we understand the most relevant details and his slides were easy to follow and informative. I would have liked a little more feedback on our homework.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This class expanded on topics of multicenter clinical trials, more concepts based (designs, types of tests, etc.) than numerical. It was a great course, I feel like I learned a lot, and I would definitely recommend taking it.
I would recommend this course (I already have) to anyone who is considering working on clinical trials. It's a non-intimidating introduction.
Outstanding course which provides a comprehensive and "real life" review of clinical trials and many of the intricacies in the design, conduct, regulation, and analysis.

A "must take" if looking to do CTs in the future and a great option if you actually want to learn some of the applied BIS that you might have been introduced to in prior courses. Pete really makes the course what you want/need it to be and is a great, clear instructor.
Good class!
Would recommend to anyone who is interested in design, conduct, and analysis of clinical trials.
This course gives a solid overview of the most important considerations in designing clinical trials.
